results.title: Are girls calculating?
results.creator_credit: Diane O'Connor and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: This videotape can be used not only in the maths-science classroom to encourage girls to see the importance of maths, but also as a valuable resource for careers teachers, and for social science units on either the workforce or sexism in society.

results.title: Frankston Motor Cycle Park
results.creator_credit: Robin Young and Victoria. Vandalism Task Force
results.brief_description:
Trailbike riding causes damage to the environment and violence and aggravation between riders and local residents. This video was made to give councils, police and motor-cycle clubs some starting points and pointers towards developing their own locally appropriate solution.
Made in conjunction with the Frankston Police Community Involvement Programme and Frankston TAFE.

results.title: Miss Mrs and Myths (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
This program looks closely at the wide range of myths and attitudes of contemporary society toward women as members of the workforce. The historical precedents for current attitudes are revealed, and facts, opinions and testimonies are presented to counter the claims of myths.

Originally produced: Adelaide : Open College of Further Education, 1979.
Women as workers (Miss, Mrs, myths) producer, Kay Hannaford ; script, Cate Kelly and Kay Hannaford.

results.title: C.E.P. What's that Got to Do with Being Here?
results.brief_description: The C.E.P. (Country Education Project) is an innovative body designed to tackle the industrial needs of rural communities. The projects are either school or community based, depending on individual educational requirements, and have a full-time regional co-ordinator. Outlines the C.E.P. philosophy and takes a close look at programs currently operating in the Ovens and King Valley regions of Victoria.
results.title_for_label: C.E.P. What’s that Got to Do with Being Here?

results.title: Skilled craftsmen: five Australians
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A lot of people consider craft a hobby. Something which is undertaken as a source of relaxation and self fulfilment. Many people, however, treat the crafts as a professional livelihood. This film shows the lifestyle of five of these people, each illustrating a different facet of the crafts: Joe McBain, a blacksmith; David Wright, a stained glass artist; Lilija Duks, a weaver; Greg Wain and Victoria Howlett, potters. Narrated by Rod Mullinar

results.title: Safe food handling
results.creator_credit: Leigh Tilson, Victorian Film Corporation and Leigh Tilson and Associates
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the need for care when handling food. Disease free handlers, working with well maintained equipment is essential, otherwise food born illness can occur.
